CControl

Basic control class from which all controls extend.

Summary
CControlBasic control class from which all controls extend.
Functions
ShowShows the control if it was previously hidden.
HideHides the control if it was previously visible.
EnableEnables the control if it was previously diisabled.
DisableDisables the control if it was previously enabled.
FocusSets the focus to this control.
Variables
xx-Position of the control.
yy-Position of the control.
widthWidth of the control.
heightHeight of the control.
PositionAn object containing the x and y values.
SizeAn object containing the width and height values.
TextThe text of the control.
ClassNNThe control class together with a number identify the control.
EnabledDetermines wether this control can be interacted with.
VisibleDetermines wether this control is currently visible.
StyleThe style of the control.
ExStyleThe extended style of the control.
FocusedTrue if the control currently has the focus.
TooltipIf a text is set for this value, this control will show a tooltip when the mouse hovers over it.
LeftThe control left-aligns its text.
CenterThe control center-aligns its text.
RightThe control right-aligns its text.
TabStopIf set to false, this control will not receive the focus when pressing tab to cycle through all controls.
WrapIf enabled, the control will use word-wrapping for its text.
HScrollProvides a horizontal scroll bar for this control if appropriate.
VScrollProvides a vertical scroll bar for this control if appropriate.
BackgroundTransUses a transparent background, which allows any control that lies behind a Text, Picture, or GroupBox control to show through.
BackgroundIf disable, the control uses the standard background color rather than the one set by the CGUI.Color() function.
BorderProvides a thin-line border around the control.
Events
IntroductionTo handle control events you need to create a function with this naming scheme in your window class: ControlName_EventName(params) The parameters depend on the event and there may not be params at all in some cases.

Functions

Show

Show()

Shows the control if it was previously hidden.

Hide

Hide()

Hides the control if it was previously visible.

Enable

Enable()

Enables the control if it was previously diisabled.

Disable

Disable()

Disables the control if it was previously enabled.

Focus

Focus()

Sets the focus to this control.

Variables

x

x-Position of the control.

y

y-Position of the control.

width

Width of the control.

height

Height of the control.

Position

An object containing the x and y values.  They can not be set separately through this object, only both at once.

Size

An object containing the width and height values.  They can not be set separately through this object, only both at once.

Text

The text of the control.  Some controls don’t support this property.

ClassNN

The control class together with a number identify the control.

Enabled

Determines wether this control can be interacted with.

Visible

Determines wether this control is currently visible.

Style

The style of the control.

ExStyle

The extended style of the control.

Focused

True if the control currently has the focus.  It’s also possible to focus it by setting this value to true.

Tooltip

If a text is set for this value, this control will show a tooltip when the mouse hovers over it.

Left

The control left-aligns its text.  This is the default setting.

Center

The control center-aligns its text.

Right

The control right-aligns its text.

TabStop

If set to false, this control will not receive the focus when pressing tab to cycle through all controls.

Wrap

If enabled, the control will use word-wrapping for its text.

HScroll

Provides a horizontal scroll bar for this control if appropriate.

VScroll

Provides a vertical scroll bar for this control if appropriate.

BackgroundTrans

Uses a transparent background, which allows any control that lies behind a Text, Picture, or GroupBox control to show through.

Background

If disable, the control uses the standard background color rather than the one set by the CGUI.Color() function.

Border

Provides a thin-line border around the control.

Events

Introduction

To handle control events you need to create a function with this naming scheme in your window class: ControlName_EventName(params) The parameters depend on the event and there may not be params at all in some cases.  Additionally it is required to create a label with this naming scheme: GUIName_ControlName GUIName is the name of the window class that extends CGUI.  The label simply needs to call CGUI.HandleEvent().  For better readability labels may be chained since they all execute the same code.
